title: Justice Dept. Official Pushes Prosecutors to Investigate George Soros’s Foundation
summary: The directive suggests department leaders are following orders from the president, a major break from decades of past practice meant to insulate the agency from political interference.

title: Democrats Dig In After White House Threat of Mass Federal Layoffs
summary: Party leaders said the administration’s plan to fire government workers in the event of a shutdown would not prompt them to drop their demands in their spending standoff with the G.O.P.

title: Top Economic Leaders Warn Supreme Court to Allow Lisa Cook to Remain at Fed, for Now
summary: In a brief filed with the court, former Fed chairs and U.S. Treasury secretaries cautioned of erosion in public confidence in the Fed’s independence.

title: Social Security Workers Struggle to Meet Demand After DOGE Cuts
summary: After this year’s staffing cuts, some people wait for hours, others sail through. But overburdened field office workers carry the weight.

title: Which Countries Recognize a Palestinian State?
summary: Ashley Wu, a graphics reporter for The New York Times, walks us through the changing map of Palestinian recognition.

title: Trump Assures Arab Leaders He Won’t Allow Israel to Annex West Bank, Officials Say
summary: After more countries recognized a Palestinian state, President Trump told Mideast and Muslim powers that he would not permit Israel to annex the territory, people familiar with the matter said.

title: Israel Attacks Yemeni Capital, a Day After Houthi Drone Strike
summary: The Israeli military said it was targeting sites linked to the Houthi militia, but a witness said a residential building was hit. A day earlier, a Houthi drone hit the Israeli city of Eilat.

title: Amazon to Pay $2.5 Billion in Prime Membership Settlement
summary: The settlement is one of the largest in the history of the Federal Trade Commission, which sued Amazon two years ago.

title: ‘One Battle After Another’ Review: Paul Thomas Anderson’s Rallying Cry
summary: The director, at the height of his powers, delivers a startling, present-day American epic, with Leonardo DiCaprio as a washed-up radical and doting dad.

title: The Battle to Make ‘One Battle After Another’
summary: Leonardo DiCaprio, Sean Penn, Regina Hall and the rest of the cast talk about filming a politically charged movie in a fraught year.

title: How One Man Is Working to Solve Los Angeles’s Homelessness Problem on His Own
summary: For years, John Alle complained to Los Angeles officials about homelessness. Now, fed up, he’s trying to make a dent in the problem on his own.

title: JD Vance Spars With Jon Favreau Over Dallas Shooting Information
summary: In the aftermath of a violent episode, political figures quickly engaged with one another on social media.

title: N.Y.C. Jail Official Broke Sanctuary Laws by Helping D.H.S., Report Says
summary: A Department of Correction investigator improperly provided information to federal agents about two immigrants, a city watchdog agency found.

title: Sarkozy Found Guilty of Conspiracy to Seek Libyan Money and Sentenced to Prison
summary: Nicolas Sarkozy, former president of France, was found guilty of plotting to finance his 2007 election bid with help from the government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

title: Ryan Walters, Oklahoma Education Chief Who Promoted Bibles in Schools, to Resign
summary: Ryan Walters had drawn criticism from liberals and conservatives alike over his push to place Bibles in classrooms and bring more prayer into public schools.

title: 3 School Districts to Lose $65 Million Over Gender and D.E.I. Policies
summary: The federal Education Department accused New York, Chicago and Fairfax, Va., of discrimination and said it would pull federal funds from their magnet schools.

title: Soybeans Were America’s Biggest Export to China. Now, Sales Are Down to Zero.
summary: China stopped buying soybeans from America in May, placing a retaliatory tariff on the bumper crop after President Trump increased levies on goods from China.

title: Sara Jane Moore, Would-Be Assassin of President Ford, Dies at 95
summary: A mother of four on the fringes of radical leftist movements, she fired at the president outside a San Francisco hotel in 1975. She had hoped to spark a revolution, she said.

title: As Mamdani Rises, South Asians Emerge as a Political Force in New York
summary: Zohran Mamdani’s upstart campaign for mayor of New York City is inspiring the growing South Asian community to be more active in politics.

title: 10 (More) Questions With Andrew Cuomo
summary: Former Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, who is running for mayor of New York City as an independent, visited The New York Times for an interview.

title: Our Best Fall Baking Recipes
summary: It’s Bake Time! Celebrate the launch of our baking newsletter (and start of the season) with these crowd-pleasing recipes.

title: The Grand Strategy Behind Trump’s Crackdown on Academia
summary: Ending the “culture of victimhood” on campus.

title: Times Reporters Answer Your Vaccine Questions
summary: We received hundreds of queries about efficacy, safety, cost and access.

title: Sean ‘Diddy’ Combs Makes a Final Push to Reverse His Conviction Before Sentencing
summary: The music mogul arrived in court on Thursday in jail clothes. His lawyers argued that his conviction rests on an unjust use of the Mann Act.

title: What Declines in Reading and Math Mean for the U.S. Work Force
summary: U.S. employers and colleges are contending with more young people who are behind academically. Some are trying to make up where schools have failed.

title: Eurovision Members to Vote on Whether to Exclude Israel
summary: The event’s organizer has called an extraordinary general meeting for November, with countries like Spain and Ireland saying they will not take part in the contest if Israel does.

title: Starbucks to Cut Jobs, Close Stores and Take $1 Billion Hit in Revamp Effort
summary: The coffee chain said it would shutter some underperforming U.S. stores and eliminate 900 corporate jobs as part of a plan to build “a better, stronger and more resilient Starbucks.”
